question: Eighty-two, Miss Pilbow speaking... Yes... ... New admission, Miss Ratched... Mister Washington! Mister Warren!
Thank you, Officer...
answer: So long, fellas... Yes, sir, it's a mighty nice fall day...

question: This way, Mister McMurphy.
answer: Yes, ma'am... I tell ya, these goons showered me at the courthouse this morning, last night at the jail, and I swear they'd have swabbed my ears out on the way over if they could've found the facilities... Hey, how ya doin', cutie?

question: Just great! See ya around! Yes, sir, I sure am gonna enjoy my stay here.
Ya know, I ain't never been in an institution of psychology before.
Yeah, I'm here on a ninety-day observation period. Short-timer, like they say...
After you, ma'am.
Man, there sure is an awful lot of poontang around here.
answer: Hold it! Good morning, boys. Great day for fishing.

question: Yeah, I was just thinking the same thing, Doc...
Why, I'll betcha there must be a million albacore and tuna running of the coast right this minute.
answer: Oh, do you do much fishing?

question: Fish! Hell, Doc, I'd like to have a nickel for every fish I landed between Point Conception and the Alaska coast...
Yup! Worked right outta Depoe Bay for just about every season since I was able to haul my own weight.
answer: My, my... Ah, who are you?

question: Your buddy is callin' ya. What's troubling ya, buddy?
answer: I want you to write me a letter to my brother for a hundred dollars to bury me.

question: You look pretty healthy to me.
How do ya know that?
You're breathin' right now. What's that, Pop? Can't hear ya, old-timer. Hell, compared to where I just come from, this is a country club. Whatcha boys playin'?
Shoot! No wonder you don't care nothin' 'bout showin' your hand. What's your name, buddy?
Well, put 'er there, Billy boy, my name's McMurphy. What I wanna know is who's the top loony around here?
answer: Y-Y-You m-mean th-the pr-president of the P-P-Patients C-Council?

question: Yeah, that'll do for openers!
answer: H-H-Harding, the m-m-man w-wants to t-talk to you, y-you're the pr-pr pr...

question: Don't you have any clubs?
Let me see your hand!
Yessir, that's why I came to this establishment for, to bring you birds fun and entertainment 'round the gamin' table... Easy now, don't smudge 'em, we got lots of games ahead of us...
Yes, ma'am...
answer: Will you come with me, please.

question: My name is Miss Ratched. I'm the head nurse here. You've already met Miss Pilbow and Aides Washington and Warren.
Mister Miller, this is Mister McMurphy, who'll be staying with us. We do appreciate the way you have taken it upon yourself to meet the other patients.
This is your bed. You may leave your things in that cabinet.
Please use your time to familiarize yourself with your new home and if there is anything you need to know, don't hesitate to ask us.
answer: Now that you mention it, I sure would like to call my aunt up in Portland and tell 'er where I am so she can come visit me.

question: All in good time, Mister McMurphy. All in good time.
Good. Now if you'll just go along with Mister Washington, he'll see that you're properly oriented. Is there anything else?
answer: Just that I'm glad to be here, Miss Ratched. I really am.

question: Good. I'm sure we'll be friends.
answer: Yeah, you ain't half so bad looking for a head nurse.

question: Yes. Now go along, Mister McMurphy. Go along.
answer: Yes, ma'am. Lead the way, Sam.

question: Yes, ma'am. Lead the way, Sam.
answer: What other work have you done?

question: Hell, Doc, I've been everything from a hoopla man with a two-bit carny show to a top mechanic and bull goose catskinner for every gypo loggin' operation in the Northwest till the Army taught me what my natural bent was.
Poker!
Yeah, but you know how society persecutes a dedicated man.

They say I'm a habitual hassler. Like I fight some. Sheeut. They didn't mind so much when I was a dumb logger and got into a hassle. That's a hardworkin' feller blowing off steam, they say. But if you're a gambler, all you have to do is spit slantwise and you're a goddamned criminal.
To tell the truth, ever since I found my natural callin' I done time in so many small-time jails I could write a brochure...
answer: Yes... Ah, do you know why you're here?

question: Well, ya know, Doc... Doesn't it say so there?
answer: Well, according to the Warden at Pendleton, you were a disturbing influence on others. 'It appears that there is a potential in him for instigating a revolt among the other inmates.' What do you think of that report?

question: I don't, Doc...
answer: Arrested on an assault charge five times...

question: That's correct, Doc ...
answer: The doctor at the prison states

question: Doc, what can I tell ya?
answer: Ah, it seems you have no other psychiatric history, Mister Murphy?

question: No, this is my first trip, Doc.
answer: Well, you're here for a ninety-day observation period, Mister McMurphy. I'd like you to understand you are here on a court order and we are responsible to the state. So, I'd like your cooperation!

question: You bet, Doc!
Yes... We were discussing Mister Harding's problem with his wife. Now, who will start? Billy.
Would you like to start?

Mister Scanlon? Mister Cheswick? Am I to take it that there isn't a man among you who has an opinion concerning this matter? Mister Harding, you've stated on more than one occasion that you suspected your wife of seeing other men.
answer: Yes, Miss Ratched, this is correct.

question: But you have no proof.
And yet you suspect her.
Why?
answer: I can only speculate as to the reasons why.

question: Have you ever speculated, Mister Harding, that you are impatient with your wife because she does not meet your mental requirements?
answer: Miss Ratched. Given all the conditions of that sublime relationship, coupled with the subsequent annihilation of all that I held to be sacred, mentally, physically and emotionally, the only thing that I can speculate on, at this late date, is how I will justify the very existence of my life, with or without my dear wife.

question: Through the ass.
answer: Is that your sense of humor or are you trying to say something?

question: Now what would I be trying to say?
answer: I don't know. I don't know, but it makes me feel very peculiar when you throw in something like that.

question: You see... it's a lotta baloney... It's all a lotta baloney...
answer: Yes, yes, Mister Bancini, now if you'll just be calm...

question: That's all it is, just a lotta baloney. Ya see, I can't help it, can't...
Well, say, buddy, is that the usual pro-cedure for those Group Ther'py shindigs? Bunch of chickens at a peckin' party?
That's right, buddy. And you want to know who pecks the first peck? Ah, come off it! It's that Big Nurse, that's who...
answer: It's as simple as that. You've been on our ward six hours and have already simplified the work of Freud, Jung and Maxwell Jones in one grand analogy

question: I'm not talking about Fred Yoong or Maxwell Jones, buddy, what I'm talkin' about is that crummy meeting and what that nurse did to you!
Huh?
answer: Electro-Shock Therapy, my friend. Five cents' worth of electricity and you are out of everybody's hair.

question: Tell 'er to go to hell anyway!
answer: And if you persist in your ways, they can always ship you over to Medical Surgery.

question: What for?
Lobotomy?
Is that your sense of humor or are you tryin' to say somethin'?
answer: Now, what would I be trying to say?

question: 'Kay, place your bets.
That's a dime, Martini.
Whadaya bet, Cheswick?
answer: She won't give me any more cigarettes!

question: That okay. I'll take your marker. How many ya want?
'Kay, all bets are down, let's wheel 'em an' deal 'em. Big king... little deuce... another king... a lovely lady... big ten... and a trey... hey, hey, whadaya say? Ya hit or sit, Martini?
That's twenty up, Martini. Hey, Taber, who's pitching the opening game?
Pardon me, ma'am, can I ask you somethin'?
How 'bout turning off that music for a while so a man can hear himself think?
answer: That music is for everyone, Mister McMurphy.

question: Well, say, how 'bout easin' it down a bit so a man don't have to shout!
answer: Mister McMurphy, there are old men here who couldn't hear the music at all if it were lower. That music is all they have, and I wish you wouldn't lean against the glass there, your hands are staining the window.

question: Sorry, ma'am... Sorry 'bout that... Sorry to have bothered you.
Your medicine, Mister McMurphy.
answer: What's the horse pill for, honey?

question: It's just medication, Mister McMurphy, good for you. Now down it goes...
answer: Look, miss, I don't like swallowing something without knowing what it is!

question: Don't get upset, Mister McMurphy...
answer: I'm not upset. All I wanna know, for the lovva Jesus...

question: You boys seem to think you've got a champ in there, huh?
answer: I don't see you scoring any points, buddy. And you're just the man for the job, right?

question: Hell, I couldn't get it up over old hatchet-face if ya paid me!
answer: She's not all that homely, Mister McMurphy. In fact, she must have been a rather beautiful young lady.

question: Good morning, Mister Sefelt, are your teeth any better?... Good morning, Mister Fredrickson... Good morning, Mister Harding; my, my, you've been biting your fingernails again... Mister McMurphy, patients are not permitted to run around in towels.
On this ward?
answer: Yeah, some creep stole my cigarettes!

question: Oh, I had them removed.
Patients are rationed to one pack of cigarettes a day. Mister Washington!
Please see to Mister Bromden.
Now you boys hurry along and wash up for breakfast... You too, Mister McMurphy.
answer: Well, say. How 'bout springing a pack of cigarettes loose?

question: After breakfast, Mister McMurphy, after breakfast.
answer: You sure run a tight-assed ship 'round here, don't ya!

question: Yes. Now run along like a good boy and see that you wash up properly.
answer: 'Kay, let's go brush our teeth, fellas... Oh, Lulu had a baby, His name was Sunny Jim, She put 'im in a piss pot, To teach 'im how to swim. Oh, he swam to the bottom, He swam to the top, Lulu got excited, An' pulled 'im by his... Cock-tail ginger-ale, Five cents a glass, An' if ya don't like it Ya can shove it up your... Ask me no more questions, I'll tell ya no more lies.

question: watching McMurphy who removes his towel as he enters the washroom.
answer: What's wrong with you guys? Why, if I'd have known how soft this place was gonna be, I'd have arranged for my transfer sooner... Look at this here, real orange juice! Hooee, that's good. Why, you couldn't pay me to leave this place! All this place lacks is a couple of sweet gals to liven things up... Stand aside, Sam, Nature's callin'.

question: What's wrong with you guys? Why, if I'd have known how soft this place was gonna be, I'd have arranged for my transfer sooner... Look at this here, real orange juice! Hooee, that's good. Why, you couldn't pay me to leave this place! All this place lacks is a couple of sweet gals to liven things up... Stand aside, Sam, Nature's callin'.
answer: Nobody leaves here till seven thirty.

question: Don't know if I can hold it that long, Sam.
Who do you like in the opening game, Sam?
Good. Good. Yes, yes, I think we should give it a trial period. So! May we get back to Mister Harding's problem... Yes, Mister McMurphy?
Go on...
answer: 'Kay, item two. Tomorrow, and listen carefully to me, you ding-a lings. Tomorrow is the opening game of the World Series an' what I want is to take a vote on switchin' the group meetin' to later on in the day, so we can watch the ballgame.

question: Just a minute, Mister McMurphy!
Please understand, the schedule has been set up for a delicately balanced reason that would be thrown into turmoil by a switch of routines.
answer: The hell with the schedule, you can get back to the schedule next week when the series is over. What I want is a vote on it right now!

question: Atta boy, Cheswick!
answer: Very well! All those in favor, please raise your hands.

question: Okay, raise your hands. Come on', what is this crap? Who wants to watch the World Series?
answer: I count only two, including you, Mister McMurphy. Certainly not enough to change ward policy. Yes. Now was there anything else you wanted to discuss, Mister McMurphy?

question: Yeah!
Yeah, how much you wanna bet?
That's between me an' myself. So why don't you boys just shove off. I got some planning to do.
answer: Maybe he'll just show Miss Ratched his big thing an' she'll open the door for him.

question: Maybe I'll just use that thick skull of yours as a batterin' ram, Sefelt.
answer: Why, my head would just squash like an eggplant, McMurphy.

question: You think it's funny, huh?
answer: Yeah, you don't know how to get outta this place!

question: Put your money where your mouth is, Taber.
answer: Yeah, yeah, you're a fucking phony, McMurphy!

question: You want me to show ya! You want me to show ya how!
answer: Yeah, yeah, show me. Show me how!

question: All right! With this thing! I'm gonna put this thing right through the window, that's how!
answer: You mean you're going to try to pick that thing up and shove it through the window?

question: You're fuckin' A-right, I am!
Okay. Who else?
Okay, Harding, you're on.
Yeah... Okay, stand aside, you guys! You're usin' up my oxygen!
Y-Y-Y-You leave him alone!
Th-th-then y-y-you're n-n-not m-m mad?
answer: No, kid, it was my own stupidity, that's what pissed me off.

question: O-o-o-oh...
answer: What we're gonna have to do is pull this ballclub together for our next play. 'Kay!

question: Try, Billy, try... Was it your idea to visit her on Sunday?
Tell us about it...
answer: I-I-I-I c-c-c-came over S-S-S Sunday m-m-m-morning after ch-ch-ch church and br-br-brought her s-s some flowers, and I s-s-said, I said, 'C-C-C-Celia, will you muh muh-muh-muh-muh...' till the girl broke out l-l-laughing.

question: What was it about her that disturbed you so, Billy?
answer: I was in luh-love with her.

question: Billy, were you afraid of her, or of her love? That was the first time you attempted to commit suicide, wasn't it? You must try to talk about it, Billy.
answer: Jesus Christ, the man doesn't want to talk, so get off his back an' let's get on to some new business.

question: Mister McMurphy, the purpose of this meeting is therapy. Group therapy.
answer: Yeah, yeah, the hell with that crap! The World Series is goin' on right' now an' that's therapy also!

question: Let me pose a question to the group
answer: What the hell does that have to do with it? This is an important event and I want a vote on it!

question: Will one more vote satisfy you?
Very well. What is it you're proposing, Mister McMurphy?
answer: I'm proposing a re-vote on watchin' the ballgame!

question: A vote is before the group.
answer: Okay, I wanna see the hands. I wanna see which of you birds has any guts.

question: Everyone in favor of changing the schedule raise his hand.
I'm sorry, Mister McMurphy, I count only eight.
But there are eighteen patients on the ward, Mister McMurphy.
answer: You mean to tell me you're gonna count those old birds over there?

question: I'm sorry, Mister McMurphy, but you must have a majority to change ward policy.
You mean you don't want their votes to count, Billy!
Sit down, Mister McMurphy! I want you to turn the television off and return to your place!
answer: Hoo-wee! Man, all I need me now is a can of beer and a red-hot.

question: I want you men to return to your proper places. The group meeting is not over!
answer: A hit! It's a hit! He's rounding first, heading for second. Here comes the throw. He's sliding... and... he's safe! He's safe! Hoo-wee! Whatta game! Whatta game! Come on, Koufax! Strike 'em out!

question: Mister McMurphy, you are deliberately violating the rules!...
answer: He's into his wind-up. Here comes the pitch. Strike on the inside corner!

question: You men remain seated!
answer: He's into his wind-up. Here's the next pitch... and it's a hit! It's a hit!

question: 'Kay, it's two outs, bases loaded as Koufax steps up to the mound... Checks the runners... goes into his wind-up... Here comes the three-two pitch... And it's a fly ball into deep center. Mantle is going back. He's going back! Back! His back is up against the wall... and... he catches it! He catches it!
Just fine, Doc... In fact, I think I might've put on a couple of pounds since I got here.
answer: Good, good, and how are you getting along on the ward?

question: Come on, Doc, you know as well as I do what's been comin' down in that loony bin.
answer: Yes, well, Miss Ratched feels that you're a disturbing influence on the other patients.

question: Shoot, Doc, the only one I'm disturbing is that old nurse and her fixed ways. That's all.
answer: Yes, that may be so, but in making a careful study of your past record, along with your behavior since you arrived here, my feeling is that you are not mentally ill and it is going to be my recommendation that you be returned to Pendleton where they are better equipped to handle your case.

question: Come on, Doc, you must be kiddin'.
Jesus, that old nurse sure wants my ass in a sling, don't she!
answer: No, Mister McMurphy, it's just that we cannot offer you the guidance and assistance that you would receive at Pendleton.

question: Guidance and assistance! That's insane! Doc, ya gotta help me.
answer: I'm sorry, but I can't keep you here.

question: When?

Okay, Chief. This is your spot! I don't want you to move from this spot! Never!... 'Kay, now, take the ball! Raise your hands, like this... That's good! That's a good boy, Chief! Now jump and put it in!
I know, goddammit! You don't have ta tell me that!
answer: So why are you talking to him?

question: I'm not talkin' to him! I'm talkin' to myself! It helps me think!
Well, it doesn't hurt him either! Does it, Chief! See, it doesn't hurt him. Jump! An' put it in!
answer: Well, I think you're just confusing him...

question: Ha! Did ya see that! Hey, Cheswick!
Come here!
Let me get on your shoulders.
Hey, Cheswick! Wake up!
I'm leaving. Goodbye!
Shhh... Hey, Billy. Billy boy, wake up and say goodbye to your ol' buddy.
So long, kid.
Shhhh. See ya around the ball park.
So long, Freddy. Don't take any wooden nickles.
Shhhh. Time to say goodbye. Hey, Hard-on. Wake up, Dumbo. Ya owe me twenty-five bucks.
I'm busting outta this place.
answer: That's nice. Send me a post card.

question: Shhh... That's for me to know an' you to find out.
answer: Bullshit. You ain't got no way out!

question: Oh, yeah?
How much ya wanna bet?
My, my...
answer: Yeah, ya should've come along with us, Miss Ratched, an' gotten a little sun on your cheeks and maybe caught a fish or two.

question: Mr. McMurphy, you had no right to take these men out with you!
answer: Yeah, that's kind of crazy, ain't it!

question: Gimme a cigarette!
Why not?
answer: I'm not running a charity ward...

question: Thank you.
Thank you.
God Bless America.
answer: Goddammit, you sly son-of-a-bitch! Does anybody else know?

question: No.
answer: Shit! This is too much! Chief, I tell you we're gonna bust outta this place an' make it all the way to Canada before they know what bit 'em.

question: Ca-na-da...
Yeah...
answer: Yeah, well, well, well. 'Bout time the rest of the world got a gander at Big Chief Bromden cuttin' down the boulevard, stopping just long enough for virgins... Oh, man, I tell you, I tell you, you'll have women trippin' you and beating you to the floor...

question: Ca-na-da...
answer: Shhh, Chief, don't talk. Never talk! Remember, this is just between you an' me. Do ya understand?

question: Shhh, Chief, don't talk. Never talk! Remember, this is just between you an' me. Do ya understand?
Hey, how ya doin'?
answer: Fine, thank you. Here, please take these.

question: What are they?
answer: To help you relax... please... Please take off your shoes. Please follow me.

question: You an' me, Chief. You know, I never got your name.
You comin' in to hold my hand?
Just fine, Billy boy, just fine. Full of piss an' vinegar! They checked my plugs and cleaned my points...
Yes, ma'am?
Thank you, ma'am.
Ma'am, I'm as gentle as a puppy dog. Why, I haven't licked the tar out of an aide for two weeks! Hi ya, Doc!
answer: Good. Why don't you join us?

question: Plan?... Oh, yeah, the plan... Yeah... Miss Ratched, would you please save a space for my aunt? She's comin' down from Portland.
Thank you, ma'am... Gotta go now, ma'am...
Thank you, ma'am. Hey, Sam, bet ya two bucks ya lose.
answer: Shit, man, tha' ain't even worth considerin'.

question: How 'bout twenty?
Bet!
I was open! Come on, let's play ball!
What kind of crap is that???
Are they all crazies?
Oh, just those guys dressed in white?
answer: No, miss, it's the other way around.

question: Replacement coming in! Harding out! Time in! Hold it! Time out! I said Harding out!
I said out!
I'm the coach!
You can come back later!
Atta boy, Mack! What's he in for?
Mack!
answer: Miss, it's a complicated case. It would take too long to explain.

question: Yeah, well, he looks like hell!
answer: Billy, it's not polite to stare!

question: I thought I told you boys to go to bed!
answer: Our prayers have been answered, Turkle! Our prayers have been answered!

question: Oh yeah...
answer: I tell ya, there's an angel of mercy standing out there, Turkle.

question: Hallelujah, brother, now get back in bed!
That angel of mercy, he ain't a she, is he?
Ah believe ya, brother. Ah believe ya!
answer: Now, wouldn't you pray for twenty bucks, a bottle booze an' a piece of that angel cake?

question: Ah'm on my knees, brother, ah'm on my knees.
What happened?
What?
Oh, that. That ain't nothin' to be afraid of, ma'am. Just ol Chief Bromden. That's all...
answer: Is he one of the loonies?

question: Is he one of the loonies?
Oh, yeah...
Hi ya, big boy? How's it goin'? Like it in here?
answer: He can't hear you, Rose. He's just a big deaf an' dumb indian...

question: Oh, no, Miss. Not these loonies. These are nice guys. Nice guys.
What smell?

Well, listen to this. He got mad at me one day. Boy, did he get mad at me. He took the light bulb, ya know. I thought he was going to cram it right up me, ya know. But he ate it. He ate the whole fucking light bulb. Now, tell me! Is he crazy? Tell me! Is he crazy?
answer: Well, Miss... I would say... I would say, yes. Yes, he's crazy.

question: I thought so.
He's dead.
answer: Oh, I see. He was a very sick man. Very sick.

question: That's what I told his mother. And she said I was crazy. Her son ate the whole fucking light bulb and she said I was crazy.
answer: I don't know anything about that, Miss. I would have to examine you first...

question: You ol' fucker!
answer: Well, I'm running a risk by letting you in, Miss. You know I'm runnin' a risk of gettin' my black ass fired. If you understand what I mean...

question: Wait a minute...
answer: It's okay, Rose. You can go with him.

question: Oh yeah! Well if ya don't mind, I'll decide on my own date!
answer: Shit, Rose! What's there to decide? There's only four of us.

question: Whaddaya talkin' about? There's at least twenty guys in there. Let's wake 'em up and get this party on the road.
answer: Now, Miss. What do you want with twenty zombies when you got a twenty gun salute looking you right in the face.

question: Oh, yeah...
answer: You better believe it, you sweet little thing. You better believe it...

question: Don't you sweet talk me you ol' spook, you!
answer: Oh, I'm all through talkin'. Now, let's just you an' me trip on down that hall.

question: Oh, there you are, Mister Turkle.
Is everything all right?
The lights were flashing on and off, Mister Turkle.
At this hour?
answer: Cleanliness is a twenty-four-hour job, ma'am...

question: What are these men doing up wandering around?
answer: Ah guess the natives are restless, ma'am...

question: You've been drinking on the job again, haven't you, Mister Turkle!
answer: Ah, no, ma'am... well, yes, ma'am... A man get awful lonely at night, if ya know what Ah mean, ma'am...

question: I want those men put back to bed, Mister Turkle!
And you haven't heard the last of this!
answer: Yes, ma'am... Night, night. Be right back, honey...

question: Don't worry 'bout the road! We'll hit the road! It'll be there when we're ready! Ain't that right, fellas? I jus' want you guys to have a good time... Are ya havin' a good time? You... you... good... good... Lez have some fun... Whatsa matter with ya... Ain'tcha havin' a good time... Whadaya want? Ya wanna drink? A cigarette... Whatsamatter, kid, what's botherin' you...?
answer: Ah-ah-ah-are y-y-y-you g-g-g-going t-t-t-to muh-muh-muh-marry her?

question: Marry who?
Candy? Hell no, Billy, she's just a good friend, that's all...
answer: Wu-wu-wu I-I-I-I th-th-think sh-sh sh-she's th-th-th-the ma-ma-ma-most bu-bu-bu-beautiful wu-wu-wu-woman in th-th-the whole world!

question: Why don't ya go tell 'er... Go on, son, now's your chance...
answer: C-C-Candy, wu-wu-will y-y-you mu-mu marry me!

question: M-M-M-Miss Ratched! P-p-p-please du-du-don't t-t-t-tell m-m-my muh-muh-muh-mummy! P-p-p-please du-du-du-don't t-t tell her, p-p-please...
answer: You should have thought about that before you brought that woman in here!

question: N-n-n-n-no, no, I du-du-du-didn't, I didn't!
answer: I don't want your mother to believe something like this but what am I to think?

question: Sh-sh-sh-she m-m-made m-m-me do it!
answer: Billy, that girl couldn't have pulled you in there forcibly...

question: Sh-sh-she did! Everybody did!
Big king, too bad...
Hear what?
answer: McMurphy killed two attendants and escaped...

question: When?
Who told you that?
